title: 110_hr160
content: The Act is titled the "Revolutionary War and War of 1812 Battlefield Protection Act" and establishes a Battlefield Acquisition Grant Program for battlefields of the Revolutionary War and War of 1812. The American Battlefield Protection Act of 1996 is amended to include a Battlefield Acquisition Grant Program for Revolutionary War and War of 1812 battlefields, defining terms like "battlefield report" and "eligible entity" as State or local governments. The American Battlefield Protection Act of 1996 is amended to establish a battlefield acquisition grant program for nationally significant Revolutionary War and War of 1812 battlefields. The program allows the Secretary of the Interior to make grants to eligible entities, defined as State or local governments, to acquire fee-simple or lesser interests in eligible sites identified in battlefield reports. The American Battlefield Protection Act of 1996 is amended to establish a battlefield acquisition grant program for Revolutionary War and War of 1812 battlefields. Eligible entities can acquire interests in sites with a non-federal share of at least 50 percent. Acquired sites are subject to land use limitations and require reports within 5 years. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress on activities under the subsection within 5 years of enactment. Additionally, an update on battlefield preservation activities at identified sites must be submitted within 3 years of enactment. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate funds from the Land and Water Conservation Fund for battlefield preservation grants. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013, and $500,000 is authorized for updating battlefield reports. The American Battlefield Protection Act of 1996 is amended to specify a grant program for Civil War battlefields, with $500,000 allocated for updating battlefield reports. The American Battlefield Protection Act of 1996 is amended to change "Repeal" to "Expiration" in subsection (a)(1) and replace "is repealed" with "expires" in paragraph (1).
